title: TSM is 0-2 in head to head matches against RNG, which is why they don't get a tie breaker.
body: Saw the question four times in the boards, so I figured I'd just answer this one time.

Never really cared for TSM that much. I'm not butthurt that they aren't going into knockout stages. 

What I do have a problem with are unnecessary rules like the tiebreaker rule. The reason I say this is because don't you think it would be better for eSports in general to have a highly contested tiebreaker match? It would generate more viewers at least. And mostly of all, it would be more consistent with how scores work. If you are tied you play a tie breaker, period.

Slaughter rule in effect. Dont let the poor team get shit on over and over again. After a while you gotta throw in the towel and let the team go home with whatever dignity is left. Forcing them to get humiliated a third time is cruel even if you do want to see TSM lose again.

Maybe I just haven't ever heard of that rule in any competitive sport that takes itself seriously. It just seems really obscure to have in anything competitive. I mean 3-3 is 3-3, aint no different than another teams' 3-3. Whether one of those teams swept the other during head to heads means fuck all if they're both still 3-3. 

But I don't make the rules. It is what it is. I'm just arguing that it would make more sense as an esports franchise to have that extra game and get those extra viewers. I mean who doesn't like tiebreakers?

No...just no. They do this in ALL sports. For example, in the NFL, if 2 teams are tied for a playoff spot, the first tie breaker is always the head to head record. It's seriously the same rule they use all over the world for any sport! If you tie with someone, but have lost to them in the head to head, so sad, but you lose the tiebreaker and they move on not you.

I think he's just thinking of baseball because it's playoff season. That's one sport where they will play a tiebreaker game if it ends up affecting playoff spots which is how you wind up occasionally having a team play 163 games in a 162 game season. The only time they use head to head tie breakers is for home field advantage to make scheduling a bit simpler.

True, they do play a wildcard game now in baseball, but that was just enacted a few years ago when they expended the playoffs to include 1 more wildcard team. But even so, if there are 2 teams tied in record, like you said, they do use head to head record to decide who gets home field advantage. This just goes to clearly show though, that the head to head record is always the first determining factor when it comes to a tiebreaker.

The wild card game wasn't what I was referring to. They've always played a tiebreaker game if it is necessary to decide who makes the playoffs, regardless of head to head record. There would've been one this year if Baltimore/Toronto and Detroit had been tied for the second wild card spot. The only use for head to head record in this case is to decide where the tiebreaker game is played.
